title: Systemic Anatomy
description: This course introduces the major organ systems in the human body by delivering the knowledge of how a system is basically composed and how different components function intimately in accomplishing their roles. The organization of each system is emphasized and illustrated using models and plastinated human bodies in laboratory demonstrations.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:  Knowledge: • describe the location, general organization, composition and function of the major organ systems in the body; • state the importance of interrelationship between different organ systems; and • provide clinical examples related to disorder of human structures.  Skills: • identify the position of different organs in situ; and • recognize the structural features of different organs and to differentiate them in situ or with the aid of plastinated specimens and models.  Attitude: • demonstrate respectfulness towards the prosected human body.

title: Cells and Tissues
description: This course introduces the microscopic anatomy of cells and tissues in the human body. Histological features of different tissues and organs are emphasized and demonstrated with the use of virtual microscopy. Topics include: histology of epithelial and glandular tissues, connective tissues and extracellular matrix, muscular tissues, nervous tissues, skin and appendages, tendons and ligaments, cartilages and bones.

title: Bioethics I
description: This course introduces students to the requisite critical thinking skills needed to analyze and reconcile a variety of ethical questions in biomedicine. By way of an interdisciplinary teaching team, cases and questions are presented to students in conjunction with insights drawn from history, philosophy, health policy, medicine and beyond. The curriculum introduces core ethical principles including autonomy, beneficence and justice and the utilitarian and deontological concerns related to these principles. The course addresses three key areas of bioethics—clinical ethics, public health ethics and research ethics and the specific ethical constructs in each field. The first unit serves to acquaint students with the features of the online learning platform.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: Recognise the relationships between humanities and bioethics; Apply the tools of ethical analysis to critically evaluate complex problems; Recognise competing interests and principles in tension; Assemble support for and craft an argument for a stance on an issue; Communicate ideas, verbally and in writing, in a clear and concise manner; and Think flexibly to apply bioethical reasoning to hypothetical medical decision-making scenarios.

title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development I
description: Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The growing interest in empathy, wellness and resilience has fuelled the design and implementation of structured educational programmes worldwide to cultivate empathy especially at a time of increasing professional burnout among undergraduates and resident trainees.Empathy in the medical setting includes the appreciation of the patient’s emotions and the expression of that awareness. Empathy is an essential learning objective and it is believed to significantly influence patient satisfaction, adherence to medical recommendations, clinical outcomes, and professional satisfaction.A key component to empathy is reflective capacity. Fostering reflective capacity within medical education helps develop critical thinking skills inform clinical reasoning, and enhance professionalism among trainees. Development of reflective capacity has been highlighted as necessary for effective use of feedback in medical education and is an essential aspect of self-regulated and lifelong learning. Failure to reflect on one’s own thinking processes, including critical examination of one’s assumptions, beliefs, and conclusions, was recently described as a cognitive component of “physician overconfidence,” a contributing cause of diagnostic error in medicine.Reflection is not necessarily intuitive, especially in students at initial stages of their medical careers.The over-arching aim of the course is to nurture and consolidate the key soft skills of an effective doctor, as well as healthy resilient personality through the development of reflective capacity and empathy.The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. The four building blocks as outlined below will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over curriculum from year 2 to year 4.1. Empathic Engagement (Year 2)2. Doctor and Society (Year 3)3. Doctor and Self- Reflection in Practice (Year 4)4. Doctor and Profession (Year 4)The four components encompass the core values of a healthy and competent doctor who is able to foster therapeutic alliance with patients, appreciate and reflect the meaning of work, being a team player as well as connection with public and society.
outcome: After completing the course, students are able to: 1. describe the key elements of an effective and empathic engagement with patients (affective, cognitive, somatic) 2. appreciate aspects of distressed or distancing empathy leading to over-arousal (sympathetic distress) or aversion 3. appraise contexts and factors leading to empathic failure, distressed or distancing empathy 4. understand the neural network of empathy, and how empathy (towards self and others, in personal and professional contexts), translates into sustainable professional practice and life satisfaction 5. understand the importance of cultivating reflective practice to maintain effective empathy in professional context 6. understand and practice process of reflective practice: reflection on content and process (context, self), reflection in action (real-time awareness), reflection on action (retrospective)

The scope of activities includes: -theme-based didactic lectures -participatory observation of role-plays, active participation in role plays, -case illustrations through artistic appreciation (e.g. in-depth appraisal of movie clips) -group discussion (in-class and web-based), -self-practice/self-reflection (in-class or web-based), -reflective writing with active feedbacks from tutors, -self-practice/self-reflection of brief cognitive behavioural exercise and/or mindfulness-based practice, -self-assessment on psychological burnout and longitudinal self-reflection with supportive feedbacks from tutors, -group presentation on thematic research or case studies, -VR-assisted experiential learning or via community projects. -self-study on suggested references and active self-reflection on the reading materials

title: Human Function I
description: This course introduces basic principles of physiological control and drug actions of various body tissues and systems. It is taught through lectures, case discussion, demonstrations, practicals and small group tutorials. The topics covered include: physiology of excitable cells, muscles, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal and renal systems, mechanisms of drug actions and pharmacokinetics, and drug actions on peripheral nervous system, cardiovascular system and gut.

title: Doctor and Patient I
description: This course describes key elements in an effective doctor-patient relationship and in effective communications with the community. The course also introduces students to the biological, social and ethical aspects of health and illness. The course has two components. Part I is a series of visits with a medical doctor to observe, understand and acquire insight into the patient presentation and the role of a family doctor in the community and the doctor-patient relationship. Part II is longitudinal follow-up of a family with a new born baby in order to observe and interact with a family with a newborn to be able to understand and describe influences on child development e.g. socio-economic background of the family, health beliefs and practices, family adjustment to the newborn, social support, community support, assessment of milestones etc. This course is delivered by a series of lectures, small group tutorials, presentations, visits to family doctors in the community, and interviews with a family on wards and in the community.
outcome: After completing this course, student should be able to:1) Describe the patient's presentation by integrating biological, psychological and social aspects of illness;2) Describe the role of the family doctor and health professionals in the community and the key elements of an effective doctor patient relationship 3) Interact and gather information from the family regarding pregnancy, childbirth and child care4) Describe the health, social and developmental issues of a child from birth to 3 months5) Demonstrate skills in reflective writing

The course provides the scientific basis in biochemical and molecular control of various cell functions, and on recent advances in genomic and personalized medicine. Topics include: cell biology, enzymology, metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, lipids and nucleotides, molecular biology, extended topics on gene expression and genetics, as well as their applications in diagnosis, screening and patient care.
outcome: After completing the course in Medicine Year 2, students should be able to: 1) describe the structure and function of various biomolecules that build up a cell;  2) understand the metabolism of these biomolecules and its integrative control;  3) describe basic principles in molecular genetics, and  4) appreciate how molecular genetics and genomic medicine advance medical treatment to patients.

title: Doctor and Patient III
description: The doctor and patient relationship is dynamic and essential in providing medical care. The therapeutic relationship enables the health professional and the patient to become cooperatively engaged and thereby effect beneficial change in the patient. This therapeutic relationship may be a one-off encounter or can be lifelong. The student should already have a deep understanding of the challenges from the doctor’s perspective and the range and variety of medical conditions of patient presentation. This course is a continuation of Doctor and Patient I and II and complements the experiences gleaned from the visits that are made in the family project during the child’s second and third year of life. The course aims to give students insights into the biological, social, psychological and medical context of care in the child's second and third year of life. This course is taught by a series of lectures and small group tutorials. There are family visits and interviews. The course ends after community and family medicine, paediatrics, obstetrics and gynaecology and psychiatry rotations so that the student has a comprehensive overview of the medical, developmental and social aspects to the family and child and the role of the community in health care. Case presentations in the interdisciplinary seminar discuss salient learning points in the course.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to:  1. describe normal physical and psychosocial developments of a child from birth to 3 years old and demonstrate awareness of common health problems in child health;  2. appraise a child's health and development and the family adjustment in terms of socioeconomic factors, health beliefs and health care provision;  3. outline key health care provisions and the role of health professionals in child health; and 4. evaluate the needs of the child and family and the role, skills and attitude of health professionals and community care facilities.

First part introduces organization of the extra-cranial structures; second part focuses on the organization of the central nervous system. The course is taught through lectures, supplemented with experiential learning in dissecting laboratory and other practical sessions. Different regions of the head and neck, including the bony components and associated organ systems are examined. The detailed blood supply and cranial nerve innervation is emphasized. This is followed by the study of the organization of the brain and spinal cord, and their control of the structures of the head and neck. Lastly, the embryonic development of the head and central nervous system including sense organs like the eye and ear is followed to allow students to appreciate how the overall complexity of this body region becomes established.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: 1. describe the organization and function of various structures in the head and neck, and the central nervous system; 2. identify major structures in specific regions of the head and neck and the nervous system; and 3. describe and appreciate the principles governing development of the head and neck including the central nervous system.

title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development III
description: Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. The four building blocks as outlined below will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over the curriculum from year 2 to year 4.1. Empathic Engagement (Year 2)2. Doctor and Society (Year 3) 3. Doctor and Self- Reflection in Practice (Year 4)4. Doctor and Profession (Year 4)The four components encompass the core values of a healthy and competent doctor who is able to foster a therapeutic alliance with patients, appreciate and reflect the meaning of work, being a team player as well as connection with public and society.After completing the course MEDU3160 in Year 3, students are expected to build the reflective capacity on mapping their external and internal resources as well as develop sensitivity to connect with the society as a knowledgeable, caring and professional physician. Medical students are also expected to explore more about self and teamwork in a clinical environment with a good sense of professionalism. A clinical medical setting is a teamwork environment with multidisciplinary professionals, e.g. doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physiotherapists, who must work together, communicate frequently, and have a common goal to care for the patients. The World Health Organization (WHO) also recommends medical students to learn the principles of teamwork in their training. Moreover, nowadays, the work duty of a doctor is heavily loaded, physically and emotionally. The development of regular self-reflection in practice would help the students to enhance resilience in managing stress. In this course, Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) will be used as a tool to help the students to reflect on how their values, needs, and personality traits greatly influence the helping process and style. Apart from MBTI, Mindfulness is recognized by the leading Medical Schools worldwide as a beneficial practice for their students and residents. Mindfulness is cultivated to promote self-care, self-awareness, and empathy with the ultimate aim of mutually improving the well–being of doctors-in-training and for the long term patient care with good quality. The course covers 3 different themes for students to explore and reflect. It includes:a. being an effective team player and negotiator; b. understanding personality type and professional Care Style through Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI); andc. Mindfulness and Cognitive techniques for medical students.
outcome: After completing the course, students are able to:  • acquire basic negotiation and helping skills in crisis scenes related to work settings  • have higher self-awareness and understanding of their own Care Style, based on their 16 MBTI personality type preferences • have specific recommendations on how they can flex their particular Care Style to increase patient’s satisfaction • reflect on how their individual personality type preferences affect the teamwork, communication and potential source of stress in clinical setting  • involve in the discussions relating to the professional issues, practical situations and attitudes necessary for the professionals • reflect their clinical experiences through peer review, constructive feedback and consultation by the medical professional • acquire and apply basic mindfulness and cognitive techniques
syllabus: The course is divided into three parts which aim to engage students' active participation and self-reflection.   Part 1: Being an effective team player and negotiator  - Teamwork in health care setting  - Introduction to negotiation and helping skills - Group discussion   Part 2: Understanding personality type and professional Care Style though MBTI  - Introduction of MBTI - Online questionnaire assessment  - Interpretation of MBTI result, Care Style and recommendations to self-development   Part 3: Mindfulness and Cognitive techniques for medical students

title: Doctor and Patient II
description: The doctor and patient relationship is essential to medical care and is a dynamic relationship. A therapeutic relationship enables the health professional and the patient to engage and effect beneficial change in the patient. This therapeutic relationship may be one encounter or lifelong. The student should already have a deep understanding of the challenges from the doctor’s perspective and the range and variety of medical conditions of patient presentation. This course is a continuation of Doctor and Patient I and takes a deeper exploration of patient’s perspective and narrative and how this impacts the patient doctor interaction and communication strategies. The student also continues to engage with the family as the child is reaching one year old and interact and observe family dynamic, child development, health beliefs and social, medical and community support.The course has two components:Part I: Doctor-patient relationship in the communityThis is a continuation of the clinical visits with a doctor. During these visits, the attention is now drawn to the patient’s perspective and narrative in looking and listening closely to the words, tones, gestures and actions used in the patient’s experience of illness, the communication and the interaction and exchange between the doctor and the patient. Meanwhile, issues relating to caring for those in decline and dying are discussed. Part II: Child and family development in the communityThis is the continuation of the family follow up project in which the students observe, interact and gain insight into the biological, social, psychological and medical context of care in the child's first year of life. This course is taught by a series of lectures and small group tutorials. There are clinical visits to family doctors and visits and interviews with a family.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: describe and illustrate communication strategies used to enhance the patient-doctor relationship; demonstrate and explain close reading and listening to the patient narrative and experience of illness; understand types of illness trajectories and the role of doctor in patient-centred care; and evaluate and contrast the health, social, family and developmental issues of a child in the first year of life.

It is aimed to help student to revise anatomy of all body regions and appreciate their relevance in basic skills in clinical examinations of the human body. title: Community and Family Medicine Module
description: This course provides 9 weeks of integrated teaching in Community and Family Medicine. In Community Medicine, three major areas are covered: Epidemiology, Public Health Practice, and Occupation and Environmental Health. Students are introduced to the principles and practice of public health, the application of epidemiological methods, and the prevention and control of communicable, non-communicable and occupational diseases. In addition to didactic lectures, students are required to actively participate in problem-solving exercises, field visits and presentations in seminars and tutorials. The clinical clerkship in Family Medicine teaches practical family medicine skills and equips students with the understanding and ability to diagnose and manage common medical conditions that present in primary care settings. Throughout the clerkship, students are taught skills in making differential diagnoses of presenting symptoms, prioritisation of multiple medical conditions and first line investigations and management of common medical problems in the community. Students also gain exposure to the basic principles and practice of family medicine, i.e., providing primary, comprehensive, holistic and continuing person centred care. The clinical clerkship consists of online teaching, case based seminars and tutorials, clinical attachments to private family medicine providers, Hospital Authority clinics and community hospitals and health care providers for vulnerable populations. To facilitate learning, role playing in workshops and clinical enhanced skills training are provided. Facilities utilised for this clinical teaching include the University Family Medicine Clinics, and Family Medicine clinics run by Hospital Authority and private practitioners, both in public and private settings across throughout Hong Kong.
outcome: By the end of the Module, students are expected to:  1. Understand and apply the principles and methods of studying health problems in population groups;  2. Know the major causes of mortality and morbidity in Hong Kong, including communicable and non-communicable diseases, and understand strategies of prevention and control of these problems;  3. Know the organization of health services and medical practice in Hong Kong;  4. Understand the principles and practice of occupational medicine and environmental health;  5. Apply the principles and methods of epidemiology in health care practice;  6. Adopt a person centred family medicine approach to clinical consultation and evidence based medicine;  7. Apply a family medicine approach in diagnoses formulation and first line management of common acute and chronic problems in primary care;  8. Counsel patients on lifestyle behavioral approach to health promotion in community settings; and 9. Understand the role and interactions of health and social issues and resources in the community.

title: Obstetrics and Gynaecology Module
description: This 9-week module includes 4 clinical rotations that are based mainly at the Prince of Wales Hospital: (1) antenatal clinic and ward; (2) gynaecology clinic and ward; (3) labour ward; and (4) O&G services in affiliated hospitals. Core materials are covered in online lectures, tutorials and bedside teaching. During the antenatal attachment, students gain understanding of normal pregnancy, the development and growth of the unborn child, and acquire skill in performing obstetrics examination. In the labour ward attachment, students participate in the care and delivery of normal pregnancies, as well as observe operative deliveries. They learn common problems and emergencies in childbirth and the postpartum period. In the gynaecology rotation, students learn common gynaecological conditions and neoplasm of the female reproductive tract. They also acquire skill in gynaecological examination. Communication skills in taking history and conducting discussions on issues regarding sexuality and reproduction are emphasized. Students have the opportunity to rotate to the O&G unit in one of the following affiliated hospitals for attachment: Princess Margaret Hospital, Tuen Mun Hospital, United Christian Hospital, Queen Elizabeth Hospital and Kwong Wah Hospital. Students are also assigned an attachment at the Family Planning Association during the module.
outcome: By the end of the rotations, students are expected to be able to manage and counsel patients on common obstetric and gynaecological problems in a primary care setting.  1. Understand how to obtain obstetric & gynaecological history from patients with common O&G problems and communicate appropriately with female patients including sensitive issues in the medical history 2. Learn how to perform obstetric, bi-value speculum and bimanual examination in female patients 3. Learn how to order appropriate investigations for common obstetrics and gynaecological conditions, derive the correct diagnosis and formulate a management plan 4. Identify pregnancy risks and provide appropriate counselling 5. Recognise obstetric and gynaecological emergencies and formulate management plan 6. Diagnose and discuss the management of common malignancies and pre-malignant conditions in female patients 7. Become familiar with various obstetrics and gynaecological procedures 8. Discuss the management of common women’s health issues and counsel patient on screening and primary disease prevention 9. Become aware of major ethical and medical-legal issues related to O&G practice
syllabus: 1. Clinical examination skills in obstetrics and gynaecology 2. Antenatal assessment and pregnancy care 3. Normal and operative delivery 4. Nutrition in Pregnancy and Lactation 5. Pregnancy complications and medical disorders complicating pregnancy 6. Contraception and family planning 7. Menstrual disorders and pelvic pain 8. Reproductive endocrinology 9. Genital prolapse and urinary incontinence 10. Gynaecological malignancy 11. Women's health

title: Paediatrics Module
description: During this 9-week clinical module in paediatrics, students participate in a range of learning activities both in the hospital and in the community. Hospital-based experiences include the wards and outpatient clinics of the Prince of Wales Hospital as well as other regional hospitals. Students are exposed to primary care paediatrics in community-based centres, including the Maternal and Child Health Centres, Child Assessment Centres, Hong Chi Pinehill School and primary care private paediatric clinics. Lectures are combined with bedside and tutorial teaching. As part of the mentorship programme, students attend interactive teaching on bioethics and communication skills.
outcome: 1. Acquire a core of basic knowledge that is commensurate with the amount of exposure students have to paediatrics, in particular clinical presentation, aetiology and pathology, principles of management, prevention and psycho-social consequences of common disorders seen in Hong Kong.  2. Recognise that (i) childhood is but one part of the human life span and that many problems of children have their origins before birth; (ii) given improved methods of care, more children are surviving chronic illness into adulthood with important medical, educational and social consequences; and (iii) childhood illness can and often does lead to problematic outcomes and consequences in adult life.  3. Use competently the clinical method to identify and plan to resolve clinical problems through:  • reliable, relevant and sensitive history taking, relating effectively to parents and children;  • thorough, accurate and gentle physical examination;  • concise evaluation of the presenting clinical problem;  • orderly planning of any further diagnostic procedures which might be indicated to establish a diagnosis;  • appreciation of the PRINCIPLES of treatment (including the roles of other health professionals, e.g., speech therapists, physiotherapists, social workers, clinical psychologists in management);  • understanding the principles underlying FOLLOW-UP assessment in order to appreciate the natural or assisted course of a clinical problem;  • awareness of the psycho-social consequences (the impact of illness on behaviour, education, family life) of illness and its simple medico-legal consequences; and  • appreciation of a broad, holistic and sensitive outlook towards the total health of individuals and communities.  4. Demonstrate skill in communicating with a child, parents and fellow professional workers, including traits of empathy, patience, kindness and counselling ability.  5. Provide at the bedside an orderly presentation of a clinical problem. 6. Appreciate the manner in which paediatric problems, their management and prevention interrelate with the practices of other disciplines, especially community medicine, psychiatry and obstetrics.
syllabus: On the first day of the module students will be given an introduction to the Paediatric Clinical Method to emphasize differences in approach that might exist between adults and children and between older children and younger children. Students will be allocated to one of eight groups (consisting of 7-8 students per group) that will rotate through the Prince of Wales Hospital and two of the four outside hospitals (United Christian Hospital, Kwong Wah Hospital, Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital and Tseung Kwan O Hospital). Lectures will be given on Mondays to all students in the module. Students will visit a Child Assessment Centre and also learn about the Student Health Service. On Tuesdays, students in groups will visit a number of regional hospitals (Princess Margaret Hospital, Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Tuen Mun Hospital, Caritas Medical Centre) and outside institutions (Hong Chi Association, Maternal & Child Health Clinic). On Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays students will undertake ward work which will involve clerking patients, participating in tutorials and bedside teaching sessions and attending outpatient clinics. Students will also participate in case studies and role play as interactive teaching on communication skills and give presentations on important bioethical topics.

title: Clinical Ethics I
description: In Year 5, students rotate to attend teaching and learning activities under four clinical disciplines namely, Community and Family Medicine, Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Paediatrics, and Psychiatry. This course introduces clinical ethics and decision at the bedside arising from some special circumstances in the clinical practice of each discipline. In the Family Medicine module, students will learn about issues in common clinical encounter, including taking a sexual history, truth-telling, breaking the bad news, and dealing with clinical errors. Through small group teachings, students able to observe and discuss challenges with experienced local practitioners.In the Obstetrics and Gynaecology module, students will learn about ethical issues through the interactive student forum and seminar, such as termination of pregnancy, reproductive autonomy in the face to emerging technologies, as well as obstetricians' role in the decision-making between pregnant women and the potential human — fetus.In the Paediatrics module, students will learn about bioethical considerations that paediatricians face while treating children for health conditions. For children, unlike for adult patients, healthcare decisions are often made by someone other than the person to be treated, i.e. by the parents/primary carers. Issues of patient confidentiality, consent for treatment, and child protection require the treating doctor to be aware of the specific needs and desires of the child, and to be able to respect and adequately address situations when the child's and parents' views and needs diverge. In the Psychiatry module, students will learn about common and unique bioethical considerations that psychiatry faces while treating patients with mental health conditions, such as patient confidentiality, consent for treatment in psychiatric illness, and capacity determination.In addition, students are required to attend the annual Lanson Lecture hosted by the CUHK Centre for Bioethics.
outcome: To develop moral sensitively to identify the ethical problems that arise in day-to-day clinical practice To determine the right course of action when unethical practices or behaviours are observed in clinical practice

title: Psychiatry Module
description: The goal for this 9-week course in psychiatry is to enable students to: 1. understand the relationship between the psychological, biological and social determinants of psychiatric disorders; 2. acquire basic practical knowledge in diagnosing and managing psychiatric disorders of major public health concerns; 3. become acquainted with the organization of psychiatric services in Hong Kong. A variety of teaching methods are employed including seminars, small-group tutorials, attendance of ward rounds, case conferences and outpatient clinics and visits to several psychiatric facilities (hospitals and community facilities).
outcome: 1. Take a psychiatric history and perform a thorough mental-status examination, cognitive and neuropsychiatric assessment.  2. Understand the principles of psychiatric diagnosis and current classification of mental disorders.  3. Appreciate mind-body connections, i.e., being aware of the interactions between psychiatric and medical diseases and the impact that mental disorders have on personal, social and occupational functioning.  4. Understand the basic pharmacology and therapeutic use of psychotropic drugs, as well the basic principles of psychological interventions.  5. Become familiar with the principles of psychiatric rehabilitation and recovery within the medical system and NGOs in the community.  6. Be aware of major ethical issues related to psychiatric and medical practice, such as mental capacity, treatment consent, and mental health ordinance.

Schizophrenic and paranoid disorders. 4. Neurocognitive disorders Common psychiatric disorders in the elderly. 5. Neuropsychiatric conditions. 6. Alcohol and drug abuse. 7. Psychiatric disorders in relation to medical and surgical diseases. 8. Major psychiatric disorders in childhood such as emotional and conduct disorders. 9. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorders and Autistic Spectrum Disorders. 10. Disorders of sleep and circadian rhythms. 11. Personality disorders, including the special relevance of psychopathic personality disorder in forensic medicine, and alcohol and drug abuse.

title: Clinical Ethics II
description: The year six medical school curriculum emphasizes clinical teaching through hospital rotations in medicine, surgery and other specialized disciplines including anaesthesia and intensive care, clinical oncology, and orthopaedics and traumatology. Besides the relevant medical knowledge necessary for day-to-day care, students must also learn to navigate the complex and multifaceted terrain of healthcare relationships between all stakeholders and the ethical challenges that arise therein.Parallel to clinical teaching, the year six bioethics course will enable and allow students to apply the theoretical models of clinical ethics in healthcare delivery. The curricular design leverages clinical experiences towards ethical decision making and resolution of dilemmas. In so doing, students will develop tangible critical thinking skills in the prevention and resolution of doctor-patient conflicts, a critical step in the transition to medical professional. Emphasis is placed on navigating difficult interactions at the bedside arising from ethically complex circumstances in the practice of each discipline. Students are expected to identify ethical issues in the patient experience inclusive of the descriptive steps required to forego or resolve ethical issues.
outcome: To learn advanced ethical theories and moral reasoning practices for recognition, prevention and resolution of ethical dilemmas in the clinical setting To acquire the reasoning abilities to identify the root causes of ethical dilemmas To gain appreciation of the multifaceted nature of the doctor-patient relationship exercised through skilled communication tailored to the needs of each patient and family  To demonstrate critical thinking in the application of clinical ethics theories via patient and family communication that in resolves clinical conflict To develop and display professional and ethical behaviours in the clinical settings, with emphasis on understanding the importance of these skills as they relate to patient interaction

title: Senior Medical Clerkship
description: The Senior Medical Clerkship consists of two ten-week modules, referred to as Medicine A and Medicine B. Medicine A consists of a ten-week attachment to the medical wards in Princess Margaret Hospital, North District Hospital, Shatin Hospital, Our Lady of Maryknoll Hospital and Prince of Wales Hospital. Students are attached to each of the above hospitals in rotation. Medicine B involves small group attachments to medical wards under the supervision of Department of Medicine and Therapeutics, Department of Clinical Oncology, and Accident and Emergency Medicine Academic Unit in the Prince of Wales Hospital. Students are attached to each of the above Departments in rotation in order to learn by daily clinical contact with patients in the respective wards. Students are encouraged to clerk patients and present during subspecialty rounds, and to follow patients’ progress during their hospital stay. Subspecialty teaching sessions are also held every Wednesday throughout the two modules. Students are attached to subspecialty activities and outpatient clinics during their respective rotations. Bedside teaching of clinical skills is arranged in small groups twice weekly. All students in these medical rotations are expected to attend medical grand rounds every Wednesday.A one-week Resident Mentorship Programme (RMP) is integrated into Medicine A. Students shadow resident mentors, learning and experiencing daily clinical work with both inpatients and outpatients. Requiring active participation in clinical activities under close supervision by frontline doctors, the programme is designed to help students develop core competencies as medical professionals. The RMP aims to nurture self-initiative, sense of responsibility, stress coping strategies, communication skills and social responsibility through experiential learning in actual clinical settings.Small group tutorials during both clerkships as well as during Resident Mentorship Programme are provided in order to further develop students' communication skills within clinical and professional settings. This includes presenting in medical rounds, writing patients' scripts and referrals, having communications with lay public concerning medical matters, handling complaints and bad news, organizing and presenting literature or decision making in clinical conferences. These skills are assessed formally in the end-of-module examinations and are also an obligatory component of final year graduating examinations. Multidisciplinary integrative sessions are maintained throughout this course.
outcome: 1. Manage common medical problems with appropriate diagnosis, investigations and treatment. 2. Deliver effective and holistic care to patients. 3. Communicate with patients in an effective, compassionate and ethical manner. 4. Make decisions rationally and ethically when faced with conflicting choices in the management of patients. 5. Appraise and use available evidence in order to provide the best treatment for patients. 6. Maintain life-long learning skills throughout their medical career.

description: The Senior Surgical Dressership consists of two ten-week modules involving small group attachments under the supervision of the Department of Surgery, Department of Orthopaedics and Traumatology, Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences, Department of Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Department of Imaging and Interventional Radiology and Department of Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery.The attachments include professional rounds, outpatient clinics and the operating rooms in the Prince of Wales Hospital, North District Hospital, Yan Chai Hospital, Queen Elizabeth Hospital, and Hong Kong Eye Hospital. Students work with qualified professionals in order to gain hands-on clinical experience (as in an apprenticeship). Students receive small group bedside teaching on each ward. Clinical management of patients in various specialties and essential clinical skills for junior doctors are the main foci in this training.Small group tutorials are held during both the Dressership as well as during the Assistant Internship period for purposes of developing communication skills in clinical and professional settings. This includes students presenting in medical rounds, writing patients' scripts and referrals, communicating with lay public concerning medical matters, handling complaints and bad news, organizing and presenting literature or decision making in clinical conferences. These skills are assessed formally at end-of-module examinations and are also an obligatory component in final year graduating examinations. Assessments include a written exam, an OSCE and a Clinical Examination that includes history taking, physical examination, interpretation of physical signs and investigations as well as management of patients with common surgical conditions.
